bill_title: to revise certain provisions regarding the killing or taking of elk and turkey which are damaging property.

bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to revise certain provisions regarding the killing or taking of elk and turkey which are damaging property. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. That § 41-1-5.1 be amended to read as follows: 41-1-5.1. Any person other than a minor under the age of sixteen years who willfully and unlawfully kills, destroys, takes or possesses in this state any animal as hereafter designated by this section is liable to the state for damages, which are five thousand dollars for each elk or buffalo; ten thousand dollars for each mountain goat or mountain sheep; one thousand dollars for each deer, antelope or bobcat. However, the return uninjured of the big game animal to the place where captured, or to such other place as the Department of Game, Fish and Parks may direct, shall constitute a discharge of such damages. However, the provisions of this section do not apply to any person, who, after first giving two days' written notice to the Department of Game, Fish and Parks, takes reasonable actions to protect his the person's land or crops from serious and extraordinary damages caused by elk, deer , or antelope. Section 2. That § 41-1-5.3 be amended to read as follows: 41-1-5.3. Any person, other than a minor under the age of sixteen years, who willfully and unlawfully kills, destroys, takes or possesses any small game bird or wild turkey during a closed season or without a license is liable to the state for civil damages of one hundred dollars for each small game bird and two hundred dollars for each turkey. However, the provisions of this section do not apply to any person, who, after first giving two days' written notice to the Department of Game, Fish and Parks, takes reasonable actions to protect the person's land or crops from serious and extraordinary damages caused by wild turkeys. Section 3. That § 41-1-5.4 be amended to read as follows: 41-1-5.4. Any person, other than a minor under the age of sixteen years, who willfully and unlawfully kills, destroys, takes or possesses five or more small game birds or two or more wild turkeys in excess of the legal limit during an open season is liable to the state for civil damages of one hundred dollars per each small game bird and two hundred dollars for each turkey in excess of the legal limit. However, the provisions of this section do not apply to any person, who, after first giving two days' written notice to the Department of Game, Fish and Parks, takes reasonable actions to protect the person's land or crops from serious and extraordinary damages caused by wild turkeys.
